page.title: 17ECOLOGY 1.
page.content: In his book "The County of Durham",pub A&C Black1924, Mitton talks of "...the coal-smoke &the stythe from the coke- ovens &brick-kilns which stunt theonce luxuriant growth of trees &plants..the noisome tar &oil which escapes downthe waterways poisoning life..". Whilst he was ready to point to the beauties of Durham, that was not a pleasant scene, but it is changing due mainly to the demise of coal-mining. Understanding the basic landscape, and its subsequent alteration to what we see now, requires some examination of local geology. Set twixt the Pennines & the Mag-limestone hills of E.Durham, here folding/wearing of carboniferous sediments has led to the outcroping of coal measures, including sandstone, limestone, and shales, thus producing the characteristic heavy clay soil _ mixed with some glacial rubbles.
